items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: Water levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, particularly in the Haddiscoe New Cut area, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: Water levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, particularly in the Haddiscoe New Cut area, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River levels are remaining high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water. Areas most at risk include The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. Although rainfall is forecast this afternoon, we are not expecting any large responses in the level of Derwent water. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue messages if necessary. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning (09/02/2022), or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Cae Howel river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the weekend. Consequently the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Llanymynech peaked at 4.3m on Sunday, 06/02/22. The level at Cae Howel is currently 4.2m and steady and at Maesbrook 0.4m and falling slowly. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 5pm on Tuesday 8th February, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Light rainfall is forecast for the remainder of the week. We will continue to monitor the situation.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: The river has now fallen below levels of concern and this Flood Alert has been removed. Light rain is forecast in the next few days. We will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue the alert if required.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: The river has now fallen below levels of concern and this Flood Alert has been removed. Light rain is forecast in the next few days. We will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue the alert if required.

River levels have risen at the Welsh Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the weekend. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge, Bridgnorth and Gravel Hill Lane, Shrewsbury. Crew Green peaked at 5.8m Monday, Montford peaked at 4.8m overnight. 
Welsh Bridge peaked at 2.47m this morning.
Predicted Peak:- Buildwas 3.4m to 3.6m Tuesday afternoon. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 5pm on Tuesday 8th February, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  No further rainfall is forecast.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Light rainfall is forecast for the remainder of the week. We will continue to monitor the situation.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.
